[LIST_ITEM] Hosts in which asexual replications occurs
[LIST_ITEM] If no replication occurs, the intermediate host is known as a transport or paratenic host
[LIST_ITEM] Plasmodium Spp. - vertebrate blood and tissues
[LIST_ITEM] Hosts in which the sexual cycle occurs
[LIST_ITEM] e.g. Toxoplasmosis gondii - wild and domestic cats
[LIST_ITEM] Gregarines - septate & aseptate (considered "primitive") - parasites of invertebrates - extracellular
[LIST_ITEM] Haemosporinids - malarial parasites and their relatives
[LIST_ITEM] Piroplasms - Babesia, Theileria and their relatives
[LIST_ITEM] All members of the phylum Apicomplexa
[LIST_ITEM] Possess a more or less developed “apical complex”
[LIST_ITEM] Possess flattened subpellucular vesicles (share this feature with the dinoflagellates and ciliates)

[LIST_ITEM] Tachyzoites can move by gliding, flexing, undulating, and rotating
[LIST_ITEM] No visible means of locomotion such as cilia, flagella, or pseudopodia
[LIST_ITEM] Functions of the conoid, rhoptries, micropores, and micronemes are not fully known
[LIST_ITEM] Probably associated with host cell penetration
[LIST_ITEM] The conoid can rotate, tilt, extend, and retract as the parasite probes the host cell plasmalemma immediately before penetration
[LIST_ITEM] Rhoptries have a secretory function associated with host cell penetration, secreting their contents through the plasmalemma just above the conoid to the exterior
[LIST_ITEM] Tachyzoites multiply asexually within the host cell by repeated endodyogeny
[LIST_ITEM] Specialized form of reproduction - two progeny form within the parent parasite consuming it
[LIST_ITEM] Golgi complex divides first - becoming two complexes at the anterior end of the nucleus. The host cell ruptures when it can no longer support the growth of tachyzoites
[LIST_ITEM] After the ingestion of tissue cysts by cats, the cyst wall is dissolved by proteolytic enzymes in the stomach and small intestine.
[LIST_ITEM] Released bradyzoites penetrate the epithelial cells of the small intestine and initiate the development of numerous generations of T. gondii
[LIST_ITEM] Five morphologically distinct types of T. gondii develop in intestinal epithelial cells before gametogony begins

[LIST_ITEM] Diet Uncooked or poorly cooked meat is eaten
[LIST_ITEM] Only members of the cat family shed oocysts
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ A cat can excrete 107 to 109 oocytes per day
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ Tissue cysts present in the flesh of eaten animals
[LIST_ITEM] Producing millions of noninfectious, unsporulated oocysts
[LIST_ITEM] Excreted in feces of cats for up to 2 weeks
[LIST_ITEM] Sporogony occurs for up to 21 days
[LIST_ITEM] Warm, moist soil - oocysts viable for more than 1 year
Distinctive Differences in the life cycle stages
[LIST_ITEM] Hosts infected by eating sporulated oocysts
[LIST_ITEM] Each oocyst contains 2 sporocysts with 4 sporozoites
Sporozoites - infect the intestinal epithelial cells undergo schizogony
[LIST_ITEM] Sexual phase of the parasite (gametogony) observed
[LIST_ITEM] Cycles through the cat rapidly (3-5 days)
[LIST_ITEM] Cat does not appear to suffer much discomfort
[LIST_ITEM] Kittens - more susceptible and some die of the infection.
[Endodyogeny - Formation of daughter cells each surrounded by its own membrane, while still in the mother cell]
[LIST_ITEM] Can infect other cells and form tissue cysts.
Require the host to be devoured by a carnivore (type 2 host) to continue life cycle
[H2] Spread of the merozoites usually prevented by the host immune response.
[LIST_ITEM] Persisting as long as the host remains infected
[H2] If tissue cysts eaten by a carnivore other than a cat.
[LIST_ITEM] Lead to the production of tissue cysts
[LIST_ITEM] Transmission via the placenta in females to the fetus occurs
[LIST_ITEM] Flies and cockroaches - can act as transport hosts
[H2] Review of Basic Facts About Toxoplasmosis.
[LIST_ITEM] Properties similar to the pathogen that causes malaria
[LIST_ITEM] One of the most common human parasites in the world
[LIST_ITEM] First discovered in the gundi, a North African rodent
[LIST_ITEM] Members of the cat family are the definitive hosts
[LIST_ITEM] Domestic cats play a major role in transmission
[LIST_ITEM] Congenital infection is the only form of human-to-human transmission.
[LIST_ITEM] Acquired toxoplasmosis can present with a range of clinical manifestations, from subclinical lymphadenopathy (the most common presentation) to fatal, fulminant disease
[LIST_ITEM] In healthy adults, infection with T gondii usually is subclinical.
[LIST_ITEM] In the immunocompetent host, infection with T gondii may be indistinguishable from infectious mononucleosis.
[LIST_ITEM] In immunocompromised hosts, toxoplasmosis may mimic other opportunistic infections, such as tuberculosis or infection with P carinii.
[LIST_ITEM] In patients with AIDS, CNS involvement is the most common manifestation, followed by pulmonary involvement.
[LIST_ITEM] Toxoplasmosis cannot be diagnosed on clinical grounds alone
[LIST_ITEM] May mimic a variety of other diseases.
[LIST_ITEM] No clinical features are pathognomonic for toxoplasmosis
[LIST_ITEM] Lymphadenopathy is the most common finding
[LIST_ITEM] An IgM-IFA titer of 1:160 or greater
[LIST_ITEM] IgM-enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (IgM-ELISA) titer of 1:256 or greater
[LIST_ITEM] Considered diagnostic of recently acquired T gondii infection
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ May detect lesion not visualized on C-T
[LIST_ITEM] ☐ May find single or multiple lesions
[LIST_ITEM] Presence of tissue cysts is diagnostic for toxoplasmosis
[LIST_ITEM] Does not distinguish between acute and chronic infection
[LIST_ITEM] Presence of either tachyzoites or toxoplasmal antigens in tissue or smears confirms acute infection
[LIST_ITEM] Tachyzoites in tissue sections or smears of body fluid
[LIST_ITEM] Difficult to demonstrate tachyzoites in conventionally stained tissue sections immunoperoxidase technique
[LIST_ITEM] Presence of the parasite in the central nervous system (AIDS)
[LIST_ITEM] Applicable to unfixed or formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue sections
[LIST_ITEM] A rapid and technically simple method
[LIST_ITEM] The presence of multiple tissue cysts
[LIST_ITEM] Majority of cases are felt to be a reactivation of a congenital toxoplasmosis
[LIST_ITEM] Marked vitreous reaction overlying the active infection
[LIST_ITEM] Healed lesion leads to a large scar
IgG antibodies are primarily measured by the Sabin-Feldman Dye Test Sensitive and specific neutralization test
[LIST_ITEM] The patient's IgG T. gondii-specific antibody
[LIST_ITEM] Becomes positive 1 to 3 weeks after infection
[LIST_ITEM] Gradually decles over a period of 5 years or more
[LIST_ITEM] Titers of 1:8 or 1:16 usually should be considered as positive.
Rising titers - 2 weeks apart indicate recently acquired infection
[LIST_ITEM] Usually appear within 1 to 2 weeks of the infection
[LIST_ITEM] Titer does not correlate with the severity of illness
A positive DT = patient has been exposed to the parasite
A negative DT essentially rules out prior exposure to T. gondii
[LIST_ITEM] IgG antibodies might not be detected within 2 to 3 weeks
[LIST_ITEM] Ratios of titers using AC versus HS antigens
[LIST_ITEM] Acute (may persist for one or more years)
[LIST_ITEM] Useful in helping differentiate acute from chronic infections
[LIST_ITEM] Best used in combination with a panel of other tests
[LIST_ITEM] Functional affinity of specific IgG antibodies
[LIST_ITEM] Initially low after primary antigenic challenge
[LIST_ITEM] Increases during subsequent weeks and months
[LIST_ITEM] Protein-denaturing reagents (urea) used to dissociate the antibody-antigen complex.
[LIST_ITEM] Avidity result is determined using the ratios of antibody titration curves of urea-treated and untreated serum.
Used as additional confirmatory diagnostic tool
[LIST_ITEM] patients with a positive and/or equivocal IgM
[LIST_ITEM] acute and/or equivocal pattern in the AC/HS test
[LIST_ITEM] Not the ultimate test for decision-making
[LIST_ITEM] Low or equivocal IgG avidity antibody results should not be interpreted as diagnostic of recently acquired infection
[LIST_ITEM] Low or equivocal avidity antibodies can persist for months to one year or longer.
[LIST_ITEM] IgM T. gondii antibodies are detected initially
[LIST_ITEM] Become negative within a few months
[LIST_ITEM] Occasionally positive IgM T. gondii-specific titers can be observed during the chronic stage of the infection
[LIST_ITEM] IgM antibodies have been reported to persist as long as 12 years
[LIST_ITEM] Persistence has no clinical relevance – chronically infected
[LIST_ITEM] The FDA recommends: sera with positive IgM test results obtained at non-reference laboratories should be sent to a Toxoplasma reference laboratory (Such as Remington or CDC Labs)
Used to detect T. gondii DNA in body fluids and tissues
[LIST_ITEM] Revolutionized the diagnosis of fetal T. gondii infection
[LIST_ITEM] Enabling an early diagnosis to be made
[LIST_ITEM] Avoiding the use of more invasive procedures (PUBS)
Allowed detection of T. gondii DNA in brain tissue
[LIST_ITEM] Highly selective against plasmodia and T gondii.
[LIST_ITEM] Possesses blood schizonticidal and some tissue schizonticidal activity against malaria parasites of humans.
[LIST_ITEM] Extend regimens to include suppressive cure through any characteristic periods of early recrudescence and late relapse for at least 6-10 wks in each case.
[LIST_ITEM] Used effectively in the treatment of pregnant women
[LIST_ITEM] Now is recommended for congenital infection
[LIST_ITEM] More potent than spiramycin and clindamycin
[H1] Drugs with Human Activity in Human Toxoplasmosis.
[LIST_ITEM] Clindamycin (binds to ribosome - inhibits protein synthesis)
[LIST_ITEM] Spiramycin (binds to ribosome - inhibits protein synthesis)
[H1] Treatment is a Function of Immune Status.
[LIST_ITEM] Measures the same antibody as Sabin-Feldman Dye Test
[LIST_ITEM] IFA titers of 1:8 or 1:16 are believed to represent infection
[LIST_ITEM] Based on the known early rise of IgM
[LIST_ITEM] Used for early diagnosis of congenital infection
[LIST_ITEM] Acute infection in the acquired disease
[LIST_ITEM] Titers of 1:10 to 1:1000 or higher are seen
[LIST_ITEM] May persist for a variable period
[LIST_ITEM] Usually becomes negative by the third of fourth month
[LIST_ITEM] Persists as low titers for a year
